sub_strands.name: Structure of the Atom
descriptions: Structure of the atom (protons, electrons, neutrons)
Atomic number and mass number of elements
Electron arrangement of elements
Energy level diagrams using dot or cross representations
Classification of elements into metals and non-metals (using the first 20 elements only)
learning_outcomes: Describe the structure of the atom
Determine the mass number of elements
Draw electron arrangements in atoms using dot or cross diagrams
Classify elements into metals and non-metals
Show interest in classifying elements into metals and non-metals
learning_experiences: Discuss the meaning of an atom and illustrate its structure
Work out the mass number of an element
Write and illustrate electron arrangements using dot or cross diagrams collaboratively
Use electron arrangements to classify elements into metals and non-metals
Use digital media where possible to observe animations or videos on atomic structure
Model atomic structures of selected elements using locally available materials
key_inquiries: How is the structure of the atom important?
core_competencies: Communication and collaboration: The learner speaks clearly and effectively as they discuss with peers the meaning of the atom and illustrate its structure.
Creativity and imagination: The learner experiments and models atoms of selected elements using locally available materials.
values: Unity: The learner respects others' opinions during group discussions
Integrity: The learner displays honesty while using digital devices to search for information
pertinent_issues: Cybersecurity: The learner observes digital safety while using devices to research atomic structure and electron arrangement
other_learning_areas: Mathematics: Working out mass number of elements
non_formal_activities: Science club presentations or demonstrations on atomic structure and element classification

skills.skill: Ability to describe the structure of the atom

rubrics.Exceeds: Describes the structure of the atom comprehensively
rubrics.Meets: Describes the structure of the atom sufficiently
rubrics.Approaches: Describes the structure of the atom partially
rubrics.Below: Describes the structure of the atom superficially

skills.skill: Ability to classify elements into metals and non-metals

rubrics.Exceeds: Classifies all elements into metals and non-metals accurately
rubrics.Approaches: Classifies some elements with limited accuracy
rubrics.Below: Classifies a few elements with prompts

sub_strands.name: Metals and Alloys
descriptions: Physical properties of metals (lustre, malleability, ductility, conductivity, melting and boiling points)
Composition of common alloys (brass, bronze, steel)
Uses of metals and alloys in day-to-day life
Rusting: causes, effects and prevention
learning_outcomes: Describe physical properties of metals
Identify the composition of common alloys
State the uses of metals and alloys in day-to-day life
Explain causes, effects and prevention of rusting
Appreciate the importance of proper use and maintenance of metallic materials
learning_experiences: Observe and compare physical properties of selected metals and alloys
Discuss and identify the components of common alloys (brass, bronze, steel)
Conduct experiments to investigate rusting and its prevention (e.g., oiling, painting, galvanising)
Use digital or print media to search for real-life uses of metals and alloys
Collect examples of metal tools from the local community and explore their uses and maintenance
Discuss safe disposal and recycling of metallic waste
key_inquiries: What are the physical properties of metals?
What are the causes and effects of rusting?
How are metals and alloys used in our daily lives?
core_competencies: Self-efficacy: The learner investigates rusting and confidently explains prevention methods
Critical thinking and problem solving: The learner analyses the importance of proper metal maintenance
values: Responsibility: The learner handles metals and chemicals safely during activities
Patriotism: The learner values local innovations using metals and alloys
pertinent_issues: Sustainable use of metals and environmental conservation through recycling
other_learning_areas: Linked to Pre-technical Studies: Use of metals and alloys in construction and fabrication
learning_materials: Samples of metals and alloys (iron, copper, brass, bronze, steel)
Rusting experiment setup (nails, water, salt, oil)
Charts and posters on metal use
non_formal_activities: Prepare a campaign or poster on rust prevention techniques
Interview local artisans or metalworkers on alloy usage and maintenance

skills.skill: Ability to outline uses of metals and alloys

rubrics.Exceeds: Outlines uses of all listed metals and alloys clearly and accurately
rubrics.Meets: Outlines uses of most metals and alloys correctly
rubrics.Approaches: Outlines uses of some metals and alloys with some accuracy
rubrics.Below: Outlines uses with prompts or limited correctness

skills.skill: Ability to explain the effect of rusting on metals

rubrics.Exceeds: Explains the causes, effects, and prevention of rusting comprehensively
rubrics.Meets: Explains the effect of rusting on metals sufficiently

sub_strands.name: Water Hardness
descriptions: Physical properties of water
Types of water (hard and soft)
Causes of water hardness (temporary and permanent)
Methods of softening hard water (boiling, use of washing soda, ion-exchange)
Advantages and disadvantages of hard and soft water
learning_outcomes: Describe the physical properties of water
Differentiate between hard and soft water
Explain causes of temporary and permanent hardness in water
Apply methods of softening hard water
State advantages and disadvantages of hard and soft water
Appreciate the importance of water treatment
learning_experiences: Test water samples for hardness using the lathering method with soap
Carry out experiments to remove temporary hardness by boiling and using washing soda
Research and present modern methods of softening water, including ion-exchange resins
Use digital or print media to explore applications of hard and soft water in households and industry
Group discussions and presentations on pros and cons of hard and soft water
Survey water sources in the local community and their suitability for different uses
key_inquiries: How can hardness in water be removed?
What are the advantages and disadvantages of using hard or soft water?
core_competencies: Critical thinking and problem solving: The learner analyses water samples and evaluates softening methods
Self-efficacy: The learner confidently conducts experiments and records findings accurately
values: Responsibility: The learner handles chemicals and experiments safely and ethically
Respect: The learner listens and engages constructively in group discussions
pertinent_issues: Water safety and conservation: The learner appreciates the importance of clean, usable water in daily life
other_learning_areas: Linked to Home Science and Life Skills: Exploring water use in domestic settings
learning_materials: Samples of water from different sources
Beakers and heat sources (e.g. Bunsen burners)
non_formal_activities: Organise a water testing demonstration in the school science club
Invite a water technician to explain local water treatment methods

skills.skill: Ability to apply different methods to soften temporary hard water

rubrics.Exceeds: Applies all suitable methods accurately and explains effectiveness
rubrics.Meets: Applies appropriate methods to soften hard water correctly
rubrics.Approaches: Applies one method with some accuracy
rubrics.Below: Applies method incorrectly or with assistance

skills.skill: Ability to outline advantages and disadvantages of hard and soft water

rubrics.Exceeds: Clearly outlines advantages and disadvantages with examples
rubrics.Meets: Outlines both advantages and disadvantages correctly
rubrics.Below: Outlines few or inaccurate pros and cons with prompts

sub_strands.name: Pollution
descriptions: Types of pollution: air, water, soil, noise and radioactive
Causes of pollution
Effects of pollution on human health and the environment
Control and prevention measures of pollution
learning_outcomes: Identify and describe different types of pollution
Explain the causes and effects of pollution on human health and the environment
Suggest measures for pollution control and prevention
Show concern for pollution in the environment
learning_experiences: Conduct a field survey to identify and record types and sources of pollution in the local environment
Use print and digital media to search for information on pollution and its impact on ecosystems and health
Debate or role-play scenarios on pollution prevention and environmental responsibility
Create posters, songs or presentations to raise awareness about pollution
Discuss the roles of individuals, industries and government in managing pollution
key_inquiries: What are the types and causes of pollution?
How does pollution affect health and the environment?
What can be done to prevent or control pollution?
core_competencies: Communication and collaboration: The learner engages with peers in environmental research and group presentations
Critical thinking and problem solving: The learner analyses sources of pollution and proposes feasible prevention strategies
values: Responsibility: The learner takes initiative in identifying and addressing pollution in their surroundings
Respect: The learner shows regard for natural ecosystems and the well-being of others affected by pollution
pertinent_issues: Environmental education and public health: Understanding pollution's role in local and global environmental challenges
other_learning_areas: Linked to Social Studies and Agriculture & Nutrition: Exploring human impact on the environment and sustainable practices
non_formal_activities: Participate in a clean-up exercise, environmental day campaign or school-based recycling initiative
Interview a public health officer or environmental expert on pollution control

skills.skill: Ability to describe different types of pollution and their causes

rubrics.Exceeds: Describes all types of pollution and explains causes clearly and comprehensively
rubrics.Meets: Describes most types and causes of pollution accurately
rubrics.Approaches: Describes some types and causes with limited clarity
rubrics.Below: Describes a few types or causes of pollution with prompting

skills.skill: Ability to explain the effects of pollution on human health and the environment

rubrics.Exceeds: Explains multiple effects of pollution with real-life examples
rubrics.Meets: Explains the main effects of pollution clearly
rubrics.Approaches: Explains some effects with general understanding
rubrics.Below: Explains effects with prompting or limited accuracy

sub_strands.name: Conservation of the Environment
descriptions: Importance of conserving natural resources (water, soil, plants, animals)
Methods of environmental conservation (afforestation, reforestation, waste management, recycling, responsible consumption)
Roles of individuals and communities in conservation
learning_outcomes: Explain the importance of conserving the environment
Describe various methods used in environmental conservation
Participate in conservation initiatives in the school or community
Demonstrate responsibility and commitment to environmental protection
learning_experiences: Engage in a tree planting, clean-up, or recycling project within or outside the school
Use digital or print media to explore conservation methods and share findings
Role-play community awareness campaigns on conservation
Design a conservation action plan for the home, school, or neighbourhood
Research organisations involved in environmental conservation and their impact
key_inquiries: Why is it important to conserve the environment?
What are the effective methods of environmental conservation?
How can individuals and communities contribute to environmental conservation?
core_competencies: Self-efficacy: The learner initiates or participates in conservation activities and promotes responsible behaviour
Citizenship: The learner understands their role and duty in protecting the environment for present and future generations
values: Patriotism: The learner shows commitment to preserving Kenyaâ€™s natural resources and biodiversity
Responsibility: The learner actively participates in conservation practices and influences others positively
pertinent_issues: Sustainable development: The learner understands the connection between environmental conservation and a sustainable future
other_learning_areas: Linked to Life Skills and Social Studies: Promoting active citizenship and sustainable lifestyles
non_formal_activities: Organise a school-wide conservation week, exhibition, or campaign
Collaborate with local environmental organisations on a community project

skills.skill: Ability to describe the importance of conserving the environment

rubrics.Exceeds: Describes the importance of conservation clearly with multiple examples and real-life applications
rubrics.Meets: Describes the importance of conservation with appropriate examples
rubrics.Approaches: Describes the importance with limited clarity
rubrics.Below: Describes the importance with assistance or prompting

skills.skill: Ability to apply environmental conservation practices

rubrics.Exceeds: Applies multiple conservation practices independently and encourages others
rubrics.Meets: Applies conservation practices with some supervision
rubrics.Approaches: Applies one or two practices with help
rubrics.Below: Applies practices with guidance or shows limited participation

sub_strands.name: Friction
descriptions: Meaning of friction
Causes of friction (nature of surfaces and contact force)
Advantages and disadvantages of friction
Ways of increasing or reducing friction in day-to-day activities
learning_outcomes: Explain the concept and causes of friction
Identify the advantages and disadvantages of friction
Suggest ways of increasing or reducing friction in daily life
Appreciate the role of friction in everyday situations
learning_experiences: Use various materials to demonstrate how surface texture affects friction (e.g., dragging blocks over rough and smooth surfaces)
Carry out activities to identify effects of friction (e.g., heat production, wear and tear, movement resistance)
Investigate methods of increasing or reducing friction (e.g., oiling, sanding, using treads)
Observe and record examples of friction in machines, walking, sports and transport
Use print or digital media to explore applications and control of friction in real-world tools and technologies
key_inquiries: How is friction useful and how can it be a disadvantage?
How can friction be increased or reduced?
core_competencies: Critical thinking and problem solving: The learner analyses situations where friction is beneficial or harmful and proposes appropriate control methods
Self-efficacy: The learner sets up and performs practical tasks related to friction independently
values: Responsibility: The learner handles materials and experiments on friction safely
Integrity: The learner records observations accurately and works honestly during activities
pertinent_issues: Health and safety in everyday life: The learner recognises the role of friction in preventing accidents and enhancing efficiency
other_learning_areas: Linked to Pre-technical and Business Studies: Understanding how friction affects machine parts and tool efficiency
learning_materials: Rough and smooth surfaces (e.g., sandpaper, cloth, glass)
non_formal_activities: Investigate and document how friction is controlled in a local workshop or bicycle repair centre
Present a group demonstration or experiment on friction and its effects

skills.skill: Ability to describe the concept of friction and its effects

rubrics.Exceeds: Describes friction accurately and clearly with multiple real-life examples and detailed explanations
rubrics.Meets: Describes friction with appropriate examples and correct terminology
rubrics.Approaches: Describes friction with basic examples and some understanding

skills.skill: Ability to identify ways of reducing or increasing friction

rubrics.Exceeds: Identifies and justifies multiple ways of increasing or reducing friction in diverse contexts
rubrics.Meets: Identifies correct and practical methods to increase or reduce friction
rubrics.Approaches: Identifies a few methods with limited explanation
rubrics.Below: Identifies methods inaccurately or with assistance

sub_strands.name: Machines
descriptions: Types of simple machines (levers, pulleys, inclined planes, wheel and axle, gears)
Functions of simple machines in making work easier
Concepts of load, effort, mechanical advantage, velocity ratio and efficiency
learning_outcomes: Identify types of simple machines
Describe how simple machines work and how they make work easier
Calculate mechanical advantage, velocity ratio and efficiency of simple machines
Relate the use of machines to real-life situations
Appreciate the importance of simple machines in improving quality of life
learning_experiences: Use models to demonstrate and identify various simple machines (levers, pulleys, gears, inclined planes, etc.)
Experiment with load and effort to calculate mechanical advantage and velocity ratio
Work in groups to set up tasks using simple machines (e.g., lifting weights using pulleys)
Discuss how machines improve efficiency in homes, farms, hospitals and industries
Search digital and print media for examples of modern applications of simple machines
key_inquiries: What are the different types of simple machines?
How do simple machines make work easier?
How are mechanical advantage and efficiency calculated and applied?
core_competencies: Communication and collaboration: The learner works effectively in teams to set up and explore machine-based tasks
Learning to learn: The learner applies concepts learned from one machine to understand another
values: Innovation: The learner creates or modifies a simple machine to perform a specific function
Responsibility: The learner handles weights, tools and experimental materials with care
pertinent_issues: Energy efficiency and sustainable technology: Understanding the role of machines in reducing energy waste
other_learning_areas: Linked to Mathematics: Calculations involving ratios and forces
Linked to Pre-technical Studies: Application in tool use, construction and design
learning_materials: Models of levers, pulleys, gears and inclined planes
Charts showing load, effort and machine setup
non_formal_activities: Organise a simple machines exhibition or challenge where learners demonstrate a working model
Interview technicians or artisans who apply simple machines in their work

skills.skill: Ability to identify and explain functions of simple machines

rubrics.Exceeds: Identifies all types of simple machines and clearly explains their functions with real-life examples
rubrics.Meets: Identifies most machines and explains their functions accurately
rubrics.Approaches: Identifies some machines and explains a few functions
rubrics.Below: Identifies machines with prompts and gives vague or incorrect explanations

skills.skill: Ability to calculate mechanical advantage and efficiency

rubrics.Exceeds: Performs all calculations accurately using correct formulas and units
rubrics.Meets: Calculates values correctly with minimal assistance
rubrics.Below: Makes incomplete or incorrect calculations even with guidance
